Patch Set 18: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start
Who owns the CableStatus? Should it create the association, not the intrusion sensor?
Cable Status is owned by EntityManager, generally we don't create associations in EntityManager.
instead of pulling, consider use a match
same: is the print necessary? Don't want to flood the log
AFAIK, hardcoded dbus paths aren't used in configs anywhere else. Can't we figure out this path from mapper somehow?
We are using this path to create association in Mapper. So it's not possible to figure out this path from mapper. We could just hardcoded 'NcsiCable' here and put the path prefix in the code tho.

I'm not sure I understand. I thought Mapper takes the existing {parent path} and {associated path} from the association definition and then creates {parent path}/{forward assciation} and {associated path}/{reverse association} having interface xyz.openbmc_project.Association. However, both {parent path} and {association path} should already exist when it does this. I suppose you could have a problem if the association definition is created before the object it associates to the parent, but that doesn't seem to be the case here. 

In the code, it looks like you have a matcher looking at the same hardcoded path already, and if that is how you are going to do it, you don't really need to specify this in the config at all.

The {parent path} and {association path} do already exist when the association created in mapper, but they only exist in EntityManager.

-it looks like you have a matcher looking at the same hardcoded path already

I've removed the hardcoded path. 

I wanna keep AssociationPath here instead of hardcoded in code to provide flexibility. If in the future, there are multiple NcsiCables, we can have paths like /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/cable/NcsiCable_1, /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/cable/NcsiCable_2.

I agree we don't want an hardcoded path in the config.
What about have intrusion sensor to query for object:ncsi_cable. If found, then create the association?
What do you think is the correct way to query the ncsi_cable? By a match or polling? We need to monitor both CableStatus configuration and NcsiCable existence here. Match probably not working here?

Maybe do createCableAssociation() similar to createInventoryAssociation() at:
https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/74cffa8846cae2b083713cbf612d43f4b7f35432/src/Utils.cpp#L534
Created another match to monitor the interfaces in /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/cable/NcsiCable.

I think it makes more sense to expose a higher level definition in the configs. For example, is there ever a "CableStatus" that doesn't have a forward association of "attached_cables"? Similarly, the reverse association can be inferred from the parent object's interfaces.

The way it is now, it is very easy to abuse this interface to set up arbitrary associations that don't really make sense in the context of network cables.
you mean something like expose a definition like {"Association": "Upstream"} in the config and generate the association [attached_cables, upstream_chassis, interface] in the code?
Yes, although probably something less generic than "Association". Perhaps something like {"Connection": "upstream"}.
Won't this run every time any interface is added to ncsiCablePath? I'm guessing it doesn't break anything if it does, but it might run unnecessarily.
Who is the consumer of this association? What is it used for?
This association will be used by BMCWeb to generate the Links between Cable and Chassis.
To reduce indentation, reverse the logic: interfacePair != cableStatusConfiguration { continue; }
give a meaningful name make it easier to read, example: propertyMap
need to call this once in case that match is setup after the CableStatus has already been created
You can use structured bindings here: `const auto& [path, interfaces] : managedObj`
Since this function may run more than once, does it need to do something to make sure it isn't creating the association interface multiple times?
can this be used instead of the loop at line 445?

No, this if statement only check if ncsi cable exists.
We still need the loop to know which board really owns the ncsi cable. (by checking 
`interface == cableStatusConfiguration`)
Is the path here going to be ncsiCablePath?

No, `ncsiCablePath` is `/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/cable/NcsiCable`.
While the `path` here will be like `/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/board/XXXXX/ncsi_cable`
Once this is created, can the cableMatch be removed?

Keeping the `cableMatch` there can give us the flexibility to update the cable association if it has been changed at runtime.
So I would prefer to keep it.
What is the purpose of this insertion?

These spaces are just to make the verification pass (otherwise the format check will fail).
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/63496 fix this issue as well.

Hi Zhikui,
Do you have any other concern?

Other than some minor comments, looks good to me. 
Resolve merge conflict.
Suggestion: Add error also to log.

I might be missing something, but from reviewing code change, looks like the association looks for ncsi cable specifically. Please make it clear that currently the association only adds ncsi cable association
I added a bit more description (at the end of the first paragraph) to specify this patch currently supports NCSI cable only.

Can you explain a bit more how sensing this cable association is could be considered an intrusion sensor?  I didn't see obvious in the CableStatus inventory item interface (just an interface name).

Is something monitoring the link state of the cable?  Is it snooping the kernel polling and async notifications of the link state?  Is it just confirming the same adapter is supplying the connection?  Or is there some other state being monitored.
